column1: Victoria (French pronunciation: ​[viktɔʁja]) is the capital and largest city of Seychelles
column2: situated on the north-eastern side of Mahé island
column3: the archipelago's main island. The city was first established as the seat of the British colonial government. In 2010
column4: the population of Greater Victoria (including the suburbs) was 26
column5: 450 out of the country's total population of 90

column1: The area that would become Victoria was originally settled in 1778 by French colonists after they claimed the island in 1756. The town was called L'Établissement until 1841 when it was renamed to Victoria by the British
Tourism is an important sector of the economy. The principal exports of Victoria are vanilla
The Mont Fleuri campus of the University of Seychelles is in Victoria.
Attractions in the city include a clocktower modelled on Little Ben in London
column5: the Natural History Museum and the Sir Selwyn Selwyn-Clarke Market. Victoria Market and the brightly coloured fish and fruit markets is the local hot spot for the Seychellois people.

column1: There are two cathedrals in Victoria
column2: Immaculate Conception Cathedral (Roman Catholic) and St Paul's Cathedral (Anglican). There are also Baptist and Pentecostal churches

column3: is in Victoria. It is mostly used for football matches.

column1: Victoria is served by Seychelles International Airport
column2: completed in 1971. The inner harbour lies immediately east of the town
column3: where tuna fishing and canning is a major industry. One of the largest bridges in Victoria was destroyed by tsunami waves from the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake.

column1: Eight of the districts of Seychelles are in Victoria.

Victoria features a tropical rainforest climate (Köppen climate classification Af) with high temperatures throughout the course of the year. The capital does have noticeably wetter and drier periods during the year
column2: with June and July being its driest months and December through February being the city's wettest months. However
column3: since in no month does the average monthly precipitation falls below 60 mm in Victoria
column4: the city does not have a true dry season month. This lack of a true dry season month is a primary reason why the climate falls under the tropical rainforest climate category. The capital averages about 2
column5: 000 mm of precipitation annually. Although being very rainy
column6: skies are usually clear to partly clear and completely cloudy days remain scarce throughout the year even during the rainiest months.
